text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text with two interrupting circular medallion illustrations centered within the text block; each illustration is preceded by a red rubric and a blue-and-red decorated initial. Wide margins are left blank.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with consistent letterforms, extensive use of abbreviations and red rubrics

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf backgrounds denote the sacred or allegorical value of the subjects; blue and green provide cool contrast on the rocky mounds; red lead used for border squares and rubrics; white highlights define feather details; layered application of pigments with occasional white stippling; original colors are well-preserved with minimal oxidation.

features: Symmetrical placement of figures around vertical axis
Border squares alternating blue and red

decorative_elements: Circular medallion frames with green and pink fillets
Blue-and-red historiated initials at chapter openings

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine brown ink outlines with consistent line weight, drawn with a quill pen
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat fields of color with white highlights, minimal hatching in shadows
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without linear perspective; depth implied by overlapping and placement on the mound

reading_order: Upper medallion first, then lower medallion

scene_relationships.position: Upper half of page, centered in text column
scene_relationships.subject: Pair of eagles perched on a rocky mound, the older bird feeding its young
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Separate allegorical theme; no direct narrative continuation
visual_connections: Circular frame with alternating red and blue border squares
Use of azurite blue and verdigris green in both mounts

scene_relationships.position: Lower half of page, centered in text column
scene_relationships.subject: Pelican in her piety, piercing her breast to feed chicks on a rocky mound
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Final image in series; concludes moral lesson on self-sacrifice
visual_connections: Border squares of blue and red

visual_continuity: Checkerboard red and blue border squares

content_theme.scene_description: Upper medallion: Two eagles stand on a low, green rocky plinth. The larger eagle leans forward with beak open, feeding its down-covered juvenile, whose head is raised. Both are outlined in fine brown ink; feathers are modeled with white highlights against burnished gold. The plinth is colored with layered azurite and verdigris, edged by a thin pink fillet. The circular frame is composed of alternating blue and red square motifs on a white ground, all set against a gilded background. Lower medallion: A pelican stands atop a similar green mound, her breast pierced as she feeds three chicks clustered below. The bird’s yellow-green plumage is shaded with verdigris and highlighted in white. Composition and framing match the upper scene. Text references in the red rubric correspond directly to the illustrated moral chapters. The decorated initials and rubric color echo the border squares, integrating text and image visually.

symbolic: Eagle as symbol of resurrection and parental care
Pelican as emblem of Christ’s sacrificial blood

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, very smooth surface with visible hair-follicle pattern under UV, ruled with plummet lines for text and illustration placement
technical_features.preservation_condition: Excellent overall; vivid pigments with minimal oxidation of azurite and lead white; slight micro-flaking of red lead in border squares; vellum shows minor cockling at edges
notable_physical_characteristics: Burnished gold leaf laid over gesso base with faint punch-work pattern
Fine underdrawing visible under ultraviolet light
Precise plummet ruling for text and frame layouts
Rubrication in red lead with clear, even application

secondary_functions: Display of the scribe’s and patron’s erudition

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This mid-13th-century illuminated bestiary leaf exemplifies the intellectual and devotional aims of monastic scriptoria in northern France. Executed in a refined Gothic textura quadrata, the page integrates two allegorical medallions—an eagle feeding its young and a pelican piercing her breast—each illustrating moral lessons drawn from moralized zoology. The burnished gold grounds and checkerboard border squares reflect Parisian illumination conventions, while the precise underdrawing and layered pigments suggest a highly professional workshop accustomed to producing luxury pedagogical manuscripts. The choice of subjects underscores evolving pedagogical methods: visual exempla reinforcing textual exegesis for sermon preparation. Iconographically, the eagle symbolizes Christ’s resurrection, and the pelican represents sacrificial redemption, tying Old Testament natural history to New Testament salvation themes. The absence of marginal grotesques and the austerity of the margins point to a primarily didactic, rather than purely decorative, function. Comparison with the Rochester Bestiary and the works of the London workshop of Matthew Paris reveals shared compositional devices—circular medallions, alternating border colors—yet the page’s technical sophistication, including gesso relief beneath gold and subtle white highlighting, marks an apex of bestiary production. This leaf thus stands at the intersection of tradition and innovation, marrying conventional moral iconography with advanced material techniques to serve both pedagogical and devotional audiences.
